reviews.review_msg: HE ZOOMS THROUGH EVERYTHING! I cannot keep up. Not recommended for people who are slow, like myself. If you enjoy a challenge, you might enjoy these lectures.
ONE OF BEST PROF @sfu~
No Comments
thought he would be good, but disappointing - in my opinion
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

The guy is pretty good. He's not very organized and has terrible notes but he knows what he's doing. Just make sure you go over the material BEFORE the lectures, it'll be A LOT easier to follow him during lectures. Exams are fair, no surprises, as long as you do homework. Also, make sure you understand mixing, and volume problems for the final.
Not very good prof. Messy writing, so so teaching methods. BUT, tests very FAIR and EASY. Take him as a prof, then just teach yourself form text. Guaranteed good mark.

Wow! Decent prof. He keeps right on track even after being interrupted by conversations every 10 mins. He repeats vital theories and concepts throughout the semester. Just listen and do homework. Recommended.
Is dedicated to teaching the concepts, the only drawback is his notes are barely legible and jump all over the place.  Make sure to attend lecture!

Terrible Professor. His writing is crude and difficult to read. His explanations aren't clear, and his notes are all over the place. He often makes typos, then just scribbles it out, however sometimes the scribble still resembles a word, which leaves you asking, "What did he just write?". You can do better than Choksi.

This guy is probably one of those most dedicated profs at SFU. He will go out of his way to help his students-even when the students act like a**es to the guy. The difference between attending lecture or not will change your grade greatly-thats how good this guy teaches

An excellent professor. I like his philosophy on teaching: that it is most important to understand and learn logic more than memorizing formulas and data. He really takes the time to clearly explain concepts, and maintains a level of mutual respect with his students. As long as you respect him, he respects you, and cares for your success.

It's not her fault the material is so darn hard..As a prof, she explained the material well, you just need to FOCUS and CONCENTRATE and be very very good in math.. It's really nice to her to make the final so easy so that everyone can pass. Also, she ended up scaling the whole thing.. so just hope you're smarter than the person next to you

The exams were quite hard. The final was the easiest of the bunch, but was still challenging. The midterms were too long to be finished in the alloted time frame. Was against scaling at first because she has 'taught the class enough to tune it quite well'. Scaled in the end. She teaches as if it is your only course.

Did a fairly good job of teaching a difficult class.  This course has a very high volume of material to cover, and Dr. Kropinksi kept a fairly rapid pace.  As expected for this level of math, expects you to do a very large amount of work. She does, however, seem to have very high expectations, which is both good and bad.
seemed like she was trying to fail 90% of the class.

Very confusing lecture. Have no clue how to copy her notes. Unprepare as well, sometimes doesn't bring overhead pens, have to copy from the blackboard. Midterms and Finals are HARD. Use differnet variables in each lecture for the same equation! LOST...
Final=disaster. Super Long + gets Super Messy(since no calculator is allowed). She's willing to help alot but i see no one attends her OffHour. well.. Other than that, she's a good prof!

Doesn't seem like she knows what she is doing unless she has prepared in advance (ie.  Can't really ask questions in class and expect them answered)  Exams were easier than my previous prof for this course.
Notes are too hard to understand.
Monotonous voice, useless notes.

Justin explains math concepts like nobody else. He is extremely clear and explains everything extremely well. I couldn't ask for a better lecturer. However, you must still go through the homework to gain an understanding as the concepts are tough. My low grade in the class is due to my own failure to pay attention and keep up.

I failed the course when taking it with another prof and got an A after retaking with Justin so you know how greate he is. Amazing prof and care about students. Final exam was clear and doable even thi I am not a science student
Tests are very, very straight forward. If you do the homework and the problems from the textbook, you'll get a good grade.

Gray enjoys stating math in a very clear and consice manner to which most non-math majors cannot relate.  It is especially difficult as he teaches first year (math 151) to new high school grads who don't speak mathematician.  Finally his open book exam method is simply his excuse for giving insanely difficult exams..to which the book will not help.
AWESOME
easiest math prof ever!!!
Best math prof ever.  It's too bad he won't be teaching for ...I think 2 years, otherwise I'd take courses with him for sure.
the course is not easy, but the prof is great; notes are really clear and organized. open-book exams, and fair marking system.

Awesome prof!  He genuinely cares about the students, honestly.  He's really fair - several times someone asked for an extension and I think every time he gave it.  Open textbook exams might seem bad but actually is really helpful.

Very fair and helpful prof, knew what he was doing and encouraged question consistently. Always mono-tone but you get passed it after first few lectures. Pretty hard but fair midterms and open book. Nice and easy to approach overall a great prof

man, he's boring, but the first day when  he stepped into the lecture hall, i thought he's an actor or something! Every single gesture follows a certain curve, never too low, never too high, but always slow. And he got a lot of color pens,too!
Gray was a good lecturer and very helpful. His tests were tough but fair.
No Comments

Very easy midterms, easy final, but very low class average.  His "conceptual" questions are cute, but irrelevant.  Moves very slow, and it takes him quite a while to answer questions.  Take calc. with him if you want an eas A.

he is very disorganized, and lecture notes/examples are same as those in the textbook.  so why didn't he just tell us to read the textbook.  Also, 56% of the class failed the final exam and we can see that how hard is his exam

Slow prof, doesnt cover anything in class. Say if u do bad on midterm u can make it up on a final. NOT TRUE !!! FINAL was a killer. Take him only if the whole class is weak, otherwise u will not get the grade u want.
worst prof ever
Nice guy and pretty organized, but exams are very conceptual and too different from the examples he gives and the assignments we have to do.

I was in the Prime section for Calculus 2, and I had Jamie Muholland and he is an amazing professor with great videos and great lectures. However, the tests were quite challenging, since I always loved Math and calculus since high school, I found the tests to be fair but they were quite conceptual and required a fairly deep understanding of math.
Jamie is one of the best profs at SFU. Would recommend taking any MATH course with him. Super organized and explains really well. Clear instructions and average tests.

Jamie Mulholland is a great prof for 152 . He is organized, caring, and has online videos. His videos are pretty good and allow you to go back on stuff at your own pace. Assignments and exams, are fair and marked on time.
Some of his explanations were so fire that I almost shed a tear, would take again!.

Great prof. Explains things well, stays on track and doesn't fall behind. He is also very accommodating if you have a reason for missing a quiz. Overall, kind, caring, effective at teaching. Only thing that I would say is final exam was VERY HARD much harder than the practice exams. However, they curved the grades and it ended up fine.
Best Math professor! Instead of watching Randall Pyke's videos, which are appalling, watch Jamies!

Gives good lectures that are only hindered by the logistics of 8 am classes. Homework is online and fair enough. For me he was the first taste of university education and looking back, I wish more profs are on his level of teaching ability and passion because most of them are far worse.

THE best professor for calculus!! I hated calculus going into it and wasnt really looking forward to this one but he made me fall in love with calculus like I never knew possible. Very clear explanations and I learned twice as much as I did in calc I because he made it easier to learn. I highly recommended!!
good teacher , but very hard exams

Math is a difficult subject in itself and very hard to teach because of its enormity. Mahdad made it as accessible as possible and is very accommodating. He will bump your grade if show progress throughout the course.

I left the class with a great understanding of the key concepts in calc 2. His lectures are useful and his pace is slow enough. Tests were fair and based on the homework questions. His accent was a little hard to understand at times.
He is funny and good at teaching. Tests are all easy. He is approachable but responds to emails very late and does not clearly answer questions and concerns students have most of the time.

Vijay is a down-to-earth guy, and definitely cracks a joke or two in lectures. I wasn't entirely fond of him writing his notes on paper, but he did spend time to rewrite them to look neater (though a bit late at times). A bit disorganized and marks are quite rigid, but he makes up for it by extending deadlines and correcting marking errors. 4.5/5

He is such a nice and easy-going guy. He is very open to questions and always finds a way to crack a joke. Although his notes were not really useful, and he writes a bit too fast and it does not help that he is left-handed when writing his paper notes, if you listen and just pay attention during lecture, you will be just fine.
Vijay is Awesome. Concepts are explained super well and always accessible for help in the course. Would highly recommend taking 152 with him.

Vijay is a great professor. He explains topics at a low level to the point that you won't come out of lectures confused. He is available out of class and provided us with sufficient material to prepare us for exams. He is generous with due dates and marking if you confront him during office hours. Don't skip class... He posts lecture notes late.

very good teacher, he goes into depth with topics and is always willing to emphasize if you don't understand something. doesn't make math unnecessarily boring or stale, and focuses on core topics without being too theoretical!
Goated prof, concepts were taught well and course was straightforward. He usually did reviews before midterms to help prepare for them. Really chill prof too.

Attendance is mandatory because he often posts his written lecture notes really late, even when the upcoming assignment is based on said notes. The weekly assignments are quite difficult and require a lot of digging around online to find answers but the midterms and the final are much easier. There are no trick questions on those tests.

I wasn't looking forward to taking MATH152 at first, as I didn't do so good in MATH150, however Vijay's lectures were extremely helpful; the exams were fairly straightforward as well. Vijay is very accessible outside of lecture, and he even made a discord server in the weeks leading up to the final exam so students could ask questions. GOATED prof

Vijay is a decent prof. He is very friendly and helpful, but he can sometimes be really careless. There are three non-cumulative midterms, and a fairly easy final as well. Honestly though, you can pretty much skip out on his lectures and do self-study or watch Jamie Mullholand videos. Not the best prof around, but he gets the job done pretty well.
Explains stuff pretty well. He made a discord server before the final and answered pretty quickly to math questions.

My love for math had slowly been dwindling. But, then Vijay started teaching me and rekindled a dying flame inside me. It was like I was watching one of those goated Indian YouTubers in real life. The dude seriously cares about his students and will go above and beyond to make sure you get what you deserve.

Vijay is a pretty solid math professor. The class was online and lectures pre-recorded. The pre-recorded lectures were OK, but if you went to his zoom office hours, he always went over the most important things and explained them very well. Before the final he had office hours everyday, even on the weekend. All in all, a very helpful professor.

Office hours were worth it, he even had a discord channel during the end. Video lectures are not well modulated though, he need to work on that. Otherwise, super helpful prof, make sure to attend office hours.

Probably the worst professor I've had in post-secondary so far. His prerecorded lectures are outdated, disorganized and confusing. He doesn't seem very concerned with students understanding the concept, vaguely re-explaining when asked. You don't want this guy for a whole semester, save yourself the trouble and watch Jamie Mulhollands videos insted

Disliked lecture hours being used as office hours- forces lectures to be watched on your own time and attend office hours, or miss the opportunity to ask questions. Not conducive to learning. Some exams were extremely unrealistic and others were blatant copy-paste jobs of the provided materials. Class essentially ended up being self-learned.

The first midterm was quite easy but the second midterm and final were hard. Mulholland's pre-recorded lectures are much more useful. Vijay's class and videos are a mess. Half the time he does not correctly answer student's questions. He does not respond to emails. I did not learn a single thing from him all semester. Be aware of trick questions.

His lecture videos are not as well made as those made by other prof teaching the same course at SFU. He didn't put much effort into them. The difficulty of tests is inconsistent. One MT and one part of the final is almost too easy and the other MT and the other part of the final is hard. You have short quizzes to do every week as well.
Great guy! The first midterm was too easy, but the second one was totally fair. He really seems to enjoy teaching and is always happy to explain things. Great prof, highly recommend!!

Tough course but he explains the topics well, although I have previous integration experience. Lectures were recorded and lecture slots were used for office hours. Explains examples clearly. Kind of seems annoyed by students asking questions but I think that's just how he speaks. Midterm was fair.

hE explains things very clearly. he is definiely one of the best profs in SFU's math department. Everything he goes over in the lecture and review is important. He prepares us very well for all exams, so there are no suprprises

Highly suggest Professor Vijay for this math course. I really enjoyed the course through his teachings, which were clear, concise and well directed. He would do his best at making seemingly tough problems very understandable. With this, participation, attendance and being prepared prior to class is very necessary.

I really enjoyed this prof and could tell he wanted the best for his students even if the class was pretty hard. You get test grades back the next day which is amazing, but you really need to put time into this class to pass. All the difficulties came from the concepts themselves not the prof.

I took this class quite a while ago but if you put in the work, study in advance (1-2 lectures), and practice often, this class is great. Not sure if it was the effort I started putting in to understand Calc (I've never taken Calculus in my life), but I actually found his classes fun. The midterms and finals were tough, but fair so practice!

A super nice guy who is also really good at math, you can tell he knows his stuff not just in calculus, but way higher than that (look at his website). Lectures are a bit rushed and messy, but he definitely cares, and his exams aren't too bad.

Tends to skip over steps while doing notes and rushes through examples or skips them entirely. Otherwise pretty good at teaching and explaining concepts. Midterms are fairly straight forward but final exam was difficult. Final marks ended up not getting curved despite a lower average.
Nathan was a good prof who was genuinely interested in the material. His explanations were great and the exams were very fair as long as you did the homework.
A fair prof who sometimes goes too fast, but you get used to the style, exams are a bit tough but a lot of practice is provided, so if you keep it up I think you'll do fine

Lectures feel rushed. He goes over the topics much faster than we can comprehend. Make sure you do extra reading outside of classes. Actually work on your WebAssigns. His tests and quizzes are on the difficult side. This is a hard course and requires lots of effort.
Good, very approachable, can be a bit too fast in explanations sometimes. Fair exams
Great prof, sometimes a tough grader, but really good at explaining concepts. If you put in the work, you'll be fine
Nathan is a very chill prof, seems nice and enthusiastic. Final was a bit tricky, but for the most part he was quite fair.
Make sure to keep up with content, final exam was a bit tough but still a very decent professor overall.
He goes at a fast pace. Best to learn stuff before hand.

At first I felt overwhelmed with his lectures and exams for him, my quizs are not perfect and the 1st midterm I had in calc 2 was around 70s, but if you genuinely try to understand the material and pay attention in class, you will strive at it, as I pumped my 2nd midterm up to 90s, so don't judge him unfairly as he is respectable and very caring

Look, this is Calc 2. Anyone acting blindsided doesn't realize that the course will be a challenge no matter who the prof is. Nathan gets unfair criticism over this, when in reality, he's a great lecturer and a genuinely helpful prof who cares about his students. Is the course difficult, yes! But with Nathan, you're in decent hands
Great professor, fair tests and enthusiastic lectures. He does rush a bit, but he uploads materials promptly and is a nice guy overall. Id recommend him tbh
Enthusiastic and caring teacher - I agree he can be a harsh marker at times and sometimes goes through notes fast, but he definitely seems to care. His exams are pretty fair too.

He is decent and his tests and quizzes are fair. Definitely nowhere near as bad as some of the reviews might make him out to be. Explanations can be a bit rushed at times, but he's approachable in my experience. Overall pretty decent.
He's fair. You just have to keep up with the material, as calc 2 can be very heavy on concepts. Study and review frequently. Exams aren't too challenging

I'll admit that his grading is a bit tougher than other professors'. His midterm 1 was fair and not too challenging. His quizzes are usually easy, as they get picked straight from the homework, so as long as you do them, you're fine. Students give him a bad rating cause they don't do the homework and blame him since he marks a bit harder.
just stay away

He may be more engaging in his other classes, but not in Calc 2. He goes over minor details and leaves important steps to the students to â€˜figure it out'. Not worth paying to be in this class if its outside your major. Questions on his quizzes/tests are theoretical; you don't exercise what you learned. Frustrating for calculus students.

got out of the midterm thinking i did a great job. got my result back and was unimpressed. the marking was very nit picky and extremely unfair. His lectures are very boring and unengaging. He picks the hardest questions for the weekly quiz and exams. During lectures he likes to "leave it up to you" to solve the rest of the problem.

the most boring, unenthusiastic prof ever + he skips over complex steps like they're no big deal. 

pretty sure he's a bit of a genius if you check out his page so it makes sense why he seems so depressed to teach calc 2.

You can tell he actually puts in a little effort in teaching during his lectures since he goes through some examples. However, a lot of the time he expects us to already know everything so he speeds through important examples and just tells us to do it ourselves on our own time. His exams are unfairly difficult and are nothing like what he teaches

He is enthusiastic about teaching and the quizzes are from the assigned written homework.. (usually the harder ones) separate from the 3 WebAssign. If you have more than 3 classes finishing all of those questions for a chance they might show up is not possible. 2 harder end questions for quiz, there is no time to think, better chance to remember Qs

Lectures are pretty much useless since he teaches very fast and skips examples very often. He also assumes you know everything so don't go to his lectures expecting to learn anything. While giving worthless lectures, his exams are very difficult and unfair. Even the quizzes are hard. Highly recommend taking calc 2 with another prof.
He was fair, and was excited to teach our class. He inspired and was excited to teach us, that is what made his  lectures enjoyable.

This is my second time retaking Calc 2 and I thought my old professor was terrible but Ilten is worse. He doesn't explain things well and goes too quickly assuming you can keep up with all the steps. I had to watch other resources and study A LOT.

Prof Ilten is clearly a very smart dude and knows his calculus well. That said, myself not being a math genius, found it very hard to follow him sometimes. He does not make the course easy. He does clearly care about the students and was an alright prof overall.

This course is difficult in terms of the time it takes to comprehend the material. I found that his exams are very fair. if you understood the WebAssign, 90% of exam questions were easier. I recommend looking up Jamie or Brenda's videos because The pace of in person lecture is just too fast for me.

I recommend saving yourself and taking Calculus 2 with a different professor. Nathan doesn't make much sense/go into detail and often doesn't finish examples. His exams are hard, and you aren't well prepared for them. When you email him, he tends to be quite rude and comes off as very standoff-ish. There are definitely better profs so avoid Nathan.

Nathan seems like a genuinely good guy, but his lecturing style simply does not work for me. He simply goes through explanations too fast. Coupled with the fact he left a lot of the finer details for us to complete, it was actually very difficult to learn without outside sources. I personally used Brenda Davison's YouTube lectures as a supplement.

Do written hw for each week, quizzes take two questions from hw that are the same. The web assign questions are annoying but free marks u get 5 attempts for each question. Go to calc workshop and ask for help, go to Nathan's office hours. Midterm and final were fair make sure u do sample exams. Go to class make sure to revise and know.

I strongly recommend not taking Math 152 with Nathan. He gives up on examples midway and says "left to you" when we have just begun learning about the topic. He seems unprepared before coming to lecture as he often makes a mistake and then just erases all his work for the example. He is a nice guy but really needs to work on his explanations.

His lectures are not enough he just gives the idea in general and expects you to study the rest and read the book. Lots of homework, you will have around 3-5 online assignments every week besides the quiz ecery Friday which you will have to solve from  24-30 questions since he choses 2 question directly from the questions he assigned. Hard exams.
Doesnt actually do anything worth watching, go to chem tutor on youtube x10 better

Prof teaches different formulas in his lecture from the textbook material he assigns. Exceptionally difficult to be learning between his method of teaching and the textbook material when there are weekly quizzes on the textbook. This course is already workload HEAVY and the prof does not explain concepts clearly.
he played ukelele for us to destress before a midterm so I choose to believe he at least somewhat cared about us so cheers to Nathan :)

Nathan's lecture is rudimentary and won't get you prepared for his exams. You need to finish all the homework each week preemptively and utilize office hours / Calculus workshop to succeed. His exams can spike in difficulty by a lot compared to his quizzes.

Going to his lectures won't prepare you enough. Read the textbook and watch Jamie or Brenda on YouTube. Class is super test heavy with homework accounting for 5% and the other 95% coming from quizzes and exams. Midterm 1 was scaled by doing corrections. Nathan is very knowledgeable but isn't a great teacher as he can skip over key steps in problems

He is great, answers question and enthusiastic but the lecture is messy and short. If you don't come to class, you probably don't understand. You MUST read textbook. Mid 1's average is 35% but he give bonus point for doing again false answer in exam. Mid 2 is better and exam is fair for me. I think he curved score because I have C+ instead C-.

A nice person, I think. Lectures are sometimes boring but it's a zoom class what are you gonna do. Personable and patient with questions during office hours. Absolutely try to do as many "optional" assignments as you can. They may be un-graded but they are not just for fun. You will be tested. Get ready to work this ain't high school. Tough tests.

Math 152 is a tough course. I think some people are confusing that toughness for Nathan being a horrible teacher. He is only given an hour 3 times a week to teach so you need to read the textbook and do all the practice problems he provides. The tests are pretty hard, but it does prepare you for the final more. He also cares and is nice. Bow tie.
very harsh on exams. The questions aren't even from homework or assignments. Very strict on late assignments, quizes and exams even if the lateness is caused by internet error

You're better off learning from online sources. Never finishes lecture slides, people don't even bother showing up to his lectures anymore. Midterm average was 35%. Stay away if you want to still like math after this class. This is coming from someone who studies day in, day out and keeps a high GPA. This class  no learning, all pain.
The example in clas is very IMPORTANT !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Know the concept!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Don't try to memorize!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Do the HW!!!!!!!!!!! And you will get good grade

Lectures are quite clear. Would recommend to do prereading.  Tries his best to answer questions. Sometimes makes mistakes then clarifies via email later. His "additional" questions on the hw assignments are brutal, I often needed help. Also, he tested a proof on one of the midterms, which caught people by surprise. Final was very fair though.

His jokes aren't funny. He makes many mistakes. Questions are not normally welcome. Expect proofs on exams. Some students seem to like him and I can't understand why. The final was much easier than the midterms and quizzes. Just do the questions from the textbook.
Super hard midterms, but super easy final!

fairly decent at explaining and very knowledgeable but i get the feeling he doesn't really care about students. Uses hard questions and proofs for exams. I found the grading to be unfair but that may be the TAs fault. I also wish he showed where marks were taken off clearly. Take if good at math as the class average for midterm 2 was 45%

Nice guy, easy to listen too. He even played the galactic empire theme for us before our final! however in lectures he skips "simple" steps in complex problems which makes it hard to follow along. He doesn't make the theory behind everything easy to understand. Tests are pretty tough, questions are significantly harder than examples taught.

Frequently skips steps while solving challenging problems and says things like "you should all be experts at this" which makes it hard to follow along.  Asks proof questions on midterms/quizzes but rarely, if ever, goes over examples  of them in class.  He's pretty organized and posts slides which helps, but his lectures aren't very helpful.

Made the midterms extremely difficult compared to the material that was covered both in lecture and homework. Often doesn't know what he's writing when going over lecture material -- frequently makes mistakes about the steps/algebra and when you talk to him after to confirm he tells you he was wrong and gives a completely different answer.

Great teacher, I may not be doing well in his class, but honestly just study and usually he is pretty good at explaining the material. I'm most amazed at how he seems to be able to answer lots of questions in a lecture hall of like 200 people, I would definitely recommend.
His lecture notes are neatly organized. He tries to make everything as clear and understandable as possible. Overall, pretty good prof.

hes a pretty good prof  if you ask him a question he will definitely give you an answer plus some extra information. He knows his stuff, clear notes, nice guy. Even tho he is a TA before, he still answer all ur questions as a TA would.
Very behind schedule, very messy
Moderate accent, do not expect much, extremely slow lectures

Making this unbiased as possible- Was polite when asking him questions usually. He somtimes posted things late. He spent too much time on less important topics but was good review. Final was hard but he prob didn't make it alone. Whoever dislikes this is probably the same people who dislike any low rating for Ralf even though they're true.

Up until the final, it was a very average experience. We were behind the entire way through even with him skipping entire sections but it wasn't a big deal in the end. That final however was awful, I don't think a single thing I studied was on it.

Barely passed the first mid and didn't do the second one due to sickness. Final was extremely hard and I almost got smoked on it. Luckily I still passed this course with a grade of C. Ralf's lectures were okay, but the tests are horrible. If you take this course with him, expect to have mind-blowing hard questions on final. Good luck.

skipped lots of lectures towards the end and still did good. Wouldn't say Ralf is a bad prof but can be rushed at times and that's understandable. If you know how to actually study effectively (and by yourself) this course is very enjoyable and is a breeze. Midterms are fair, final is hard-but curved so not the end of the world. Overall good class.

Ralf seems like a nice person but he was constantly late to class and fell behind not even a couple weeks into the semester. He then rushed through several topics at the end that ended up being important for the final. We sometimes learned things the day before the corresponding Webassign was due. If he managed his time better, he would be great.

He is often late and disorganized, and he will not care if he is behind on material (often by weeks) as he will just cram stuff into lectures at the end without going into any reasonable depth. His midterms and quizzes are fair, but the final exam is not even something you can prepare for; 3 hours wondering whether youre sane or not (not kidding)

His lectures are not very helpful, but he tries to teach well. He's just not great at communicating his thoughts a lot of the time so most of the time his lectures are just his stream of consciousness. His midterms are slightly challenging, but the final is what you should look out for. It'll kill you. It's sixteen pages of hell...

Ralf is very unorganized and consistently comes to class late. He rushes through the material as well because he is not good at managing his time. He'll go too slow at the beginning of the semester but then rush you so bad later. He says "uhhhh" for half of the lecture and it just seems like he's learning the content at the same time as we are.
That final exam alone is enough to give him a one

Ralf tries his best. His lectures are really boring, so you're better off just watching Jamie's videos. He is usually pretty disorganized and will often come to class late, so expect to fall behind in material often. The only way he catches up is by blowing through 3 different topics in 50 minutes and telling you the filled out notes are on Canvas.
He is not good at teaching and his exams are really hard. Avoid him if possible.
ralf is a nice guy but always late to class, doesn't post resources quick enough, does not respond to emails punctually, and is behind in lecture schedule

Some of these reviews are true, yet some quite far from it. Ralf's biggest problem is time management, however he's an otherwise solid prof. Personally I've found CALC 2 to be easier than CALC1 and all you really need to do is put in the work and practice. 

These reviews make the course seem worse than what it actually is.

I feel that Ralf is actually a good professor, but his professionalism is lacking significantly. He constantly shows up late for lectures, spends too much time on a topic, and falls being only to catch up by covering 2-3 topics in one lecture, which makes it extremely difficult to learn. Just don't take an 8:30 class with him and you'll be fine :)
Ralf if you see this please take it as a sign to give up teaching.

His uninspiring teaching style compounded with his disorganized lesson planning and tardiness makes MATH152 with him an unbearable course to take. If you like your homework due after the day you're taught the content and being in a confused daze for 50 minutes, this is the course for you. However, if you're a regular student trying to get by, RUN.

I've never rated a professor before but felt the need to just because of how bad Ralf is. If you have the chance, STEER CLEAR. Ralf makes learning so unnecessarily difficult due to his poor time management and lack of communication and planning.

My main issue with this prof is that he posts quiz assignments very late (the day of, or before the quiz), and is slow at teaching. In some quizzes, the questions he puts in are not even from the quiz assignments. His teaching can be unclear as well so make sure to watch Jamie Mulholland's youtube lectures to fully understand the material.

He does not give time warnings during exams, consistently goes over class time and gets upset at students for packing when class ends.

If this was highschool it may be acceptable, but with the amount of tuition Im paying, I would except more organization and sharpness.

Did I mention he doesn't give time warnings during exam? probably forgot lol

He's a nice guy and will be more than willing to help if you ask him. That being said, he rushed through a lot of material near the end (five sections in one lecture?) which ended up being a large chunk of the final exam material. Also, check out the textbook study guide (available at the library) for lots of completed example problems. It saved me
